content:
• Tuesday, June 16, 2015
  • DMDA

    Dex Media reverses to 16.5% gain in closing minutes

    • Dex Media (DXM) sunk 11% to a 52-week low early this afternoon -- but that was before trades in the last four minutes of the market session lifted it to a 16.5% gain on the day, recouping a few days of losses.
    • Volume was normal today on no apparent news. Amid sales turmoil, the company this spring has mostly dealt with executive turnover (as its sales chief resigned just before a poor Q1 earnings report) and board shuffles (John Slater left the board at seven members, and Dex decided to keep two board members who lost re-election).
    • On the positive side, in March the company wrapped its second straight fiscal year of revenue growth (to $1.82B).
    • Related: 4 Reasons Dex Media Is Worth A Look Into 1Q15 Results Next Week (May. 01 2015)
    • Related: Dex Media: More Questions Than Answers After The Earnings Call (Mar. 19 2015)
     
     
     
     
    | 6:57 PM | 5 Comments
  • NR

    Newpark Resources sees weaker Q2 sales activity, especially in Mats

    • Newpark Resources (NYSE:NR) -3.5% AH after saying it has seen a modest reduction in Fluids Systems revenues since May, driven by the continued slide in U.S. rig counts and weather-related delays; however, NR does not expect lower revenue in Fluids to significantly impact its segment operating income expectation of modest sequential improvement for Q2.
    • In the Mats and Integrated Services segment, NR says it has seen a "considerable decline" in sales activity during Q2, as mat purchases from E&P customers have declined sharply amid weak oil prices; as a result, NR now expect Q2 Mats revenue of $22M-$24M rather than relatively stable vs. Q1, with an operating margin of 25%-30% rather than 30%-plus.
     
     
     
     
    | 6:18 PM

  • After Hours Gainers / Losers

    • Top gainers, as of 5:15 p.m.: BOBE +3.8%. OTC:ANTH +3.5%. AAVL +2.1%. KEYW +1.6%. BLCM +1.2%.
    • Top losers, as of 5:15 p.m.: DTEA -12.4%. GLNG -1.4%. MLNX -1.2%.MRVL -1.1%.JD -1.0%.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:38 PM
  • FTR

    Frontier receiving rural broadband funds, upgrade from Bernstein

    • Frontier Communications (FTR +1.8%) gained today after saying it accepted support from the FCC, via the Connect America Fund, of $283M in funds to deploy high-cost rural broadband.
    • The company accepted the funds ahead of an Aug. 27 deadline "because we are eager to start building the infrastructure necessary to provide service to these markets as soon as possible," says CEO Dan McCarthy.
    • The new funds come from Phase II of the project; in Phase I, Frontier invested $133M in project funding to deploy or upgrade broadband to nearly 200K locations. The new project targets 650K rural locations throughout Frontier's 28-state service area.
    • Meanwhile, Sanford Bernstein's Paul de Sa upgraded the stock to Outperform, from Market Perform, pointing to revised modeling incorporating an expected first-half 2016 completion to its wireline deal with Verizon.
    • The FCC subsidies mean about $130M in annual incremental cash the Frontier will start to receive in Q3, de Sa notes. Also, there's more stability to the business than is seen in quarter-to-quarter reporting, and he believes that even with a slow price recovery, the dividend is safe.
    • Bernstein reduced the price target, though, to $6 from $7.08. Shares closed today at $4.97.
     
     
     
     
    | 5:15 PM | 3 Comments
  • AZUR

    Azure Midstream to launch 3.5M-unit offering

    • Azure Midstream Partners (NYSE:AZUR) -8.5% AH after announcing a public offering of 3.5M common units, with an underwriters option to purchase up to an additional 525K units.
    • AZUR says it plans to use the proceeds to reduce outstanding debt under its revolving credit facility, and may re-borrow to fund potential future acquisitions or general partnership purposes.
    • In a quarterly update, AZUR  says it expect to generate adjusted Q1 EBITDA 15%-25% higher than its pro forma adjusted EBITDA for the quarter.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:56 PM
  • HDP

    Mizuho starts Hortonworks at Outperform, sees a buyout target

    • Mizuho's Abhey Lamba has provided Hortonworks (NASDAQ:HDP) with an Outperform rating and $31 target after the close.
    • HDP +1.5% AH to $26.46. Oppenheimer provided bullish coverage on the Hadoop software/services provider in late May.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:37 PM
  • BOBE

    Steady comp growth forecast by Bob Evans Farms

    • Bob Evans Farms (NASDAQ:BOBE) reports same-store sales rose 2.1% in Q4.
    • BEF Foods sales fell 1.2% to $94.2M during the quarter.
    • Higher labor costs and elevated egg prices were a drag on the bottom line.
    • The company says it expects low-single digit same-store sales growth for FQ2 through the balance of the fiscal year as measures to reduce guest discounts are applied. FQ1 same-store sales are seen as coming in flat.
    • FY16 revenue of $1.34B-$1.41B vs. $1.37B consensus and EPS of $1.75-$1.95 vs. $1.86 consensus forecast.
    • Previously: Bob Evans Farms beats by $0.15, beats on revenue
    • BOBE -0.73% after hours.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:22 PM
  • NYRT

    New York REIT closes with 3.1% gain after investor urges action

    • The stock price's discount to NAV has risen to 30%, says Sorin Capital Management in a letter to New York REIT (NYRT +3.1%) CEO Michael Happel. The deterioration in the past few weeks, according to Sorin, is due primarily to the company's abandonment of its strategic options exploration process and the resignation of CFO/COO Gregory Smith.
    • Sorin Capital is among NYRT's largest shareholders.
    • Nick Schorsch may be gone from NYRT, but the company continues its relationship with Schorsch's AR Capital, says Sorin, thus impeding steps to address the value gap issue, and exacerbating the poor stock price performance.
    • "More of the same" from the Board and management is neither a strategic alternative nor what shareholders should expect or deserve."
    • Responding, New York REIT says it's actively pursuing several previously-announced strategies to maximize long-term shareholder value.
     
     
     
     
    | 4:18 PM | 1 Comment
  • GBX

    Greenbrier cut to Hold from Buy at Stifel, citing slowing railcar orders

    • Greenbrier (GBX -10.4%) tumbles more than 10% after Stifel downgrades shares to Hold from Buy, citing an expected decline in industry production levels after 2015.
    • Stifel believes the prospect for declining industry production levels after 2015, leading to the possibility of multiple compression for the industry as a whole, could prevent GBX shares from continuing to outperform the market during the next 12 months after rising 11% YTD vs. +1% for the S&P 500.
    • The firm foresees industry production levels peaking this year at 84K, then declining to 74K in 2016 and 64K in 2017, driven by an unfavorable outlook for deliveries of tank cars and covered hoppers due to the fall in oil prices.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:56 PM | 14 Comments
  • CREE

    Cree +2.9%; strong short-term call-buying seen

    • CREE has seen 4,658 contracts trade for June 26 calls sporting a $31.50 strike price. Nearly 1K contracts have also been traded for June 19 calls with strike prices ranging from $30.50-$31.50. Shares have rallied on a day the Nasdaq is up 0.5%.
    • Separately, Cree announced this morning it's partnering with home automation hardware/software provider SmartThings to make its Connected LED bulbs compatible with SmartThings' platform.
    • Last month: Cree CEO buys 10K shares
     
     
     
     
    | 3:53 PM | 2 Comments
  • OPTT

    Ocean Power +24% as PB40 PowerBuoy wins final approval for deployment

    • Ocean Power Tech (OPTT +24.3%) pushes to strong gains after announcing it received final permit approval from the New York District Army Corps of Engineers for the PB40 PowerBuoy system designed to transmit electricity to shore by an underwater power cable, and providing notice periods to the U.S. Coast Guard and other parties involved in the permitting process.
    • The PB40 will be deployed ~30 nautical miles southeast of New York Harbor.
    • OPTT also says the permitting process for its APB-350 A1 deployment is well underway and anticipated for this summer.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:47 PM
  • FTNT

    Fortinet +3.6%; Oppenheimer hikes target, reports strong checks

    • Oppenheimer's Shaul Eyal (Outperform rating): "We are raising our PT to $46 from $39, nudging our 2Q revenue estimate higher following mid-Q checks suggesting (yet again) FTNT's business is tracking ahead of guidance."
    • He adds his bullish stance on the UTM appliance leader's sales is based on growing $500K+ Q2 contract wins, strong telecom sales, ongoing high-end appliance traction, and strong demand across all geographies.
    • Shares have made new highs, and (thanks to both good earnings news and strong investor interest in nearly anything cybersecurity-related) are up 39% YTD.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:44 PM

  • Consumer staples perk up after Coty play

    • The Consumer Staples ETF (NYSEARCA:XLP) is up 1.1% to outpace broad market averages.
    • The rally is due in part to Coty's aggressive play to land Procter & Gamble's beauty assets which has given some life to a list of names in the sector.
    • Bank of America Merrill Lynch has also called the staples sector undervalued.
    • Related ETFs: PSL, PSCC.
    • Previously: Coty acquires beauty product lines from P&G for $12B (June 15)
     
     
     
     
    | 3:42 PM
  • AAPL

    MobileIron +7.9%; company working with Apple on iOS enterprise deployments

    • TechCrunch states Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL), which has been stepping up its efforts to grow enterprise sales, is working with enterprise mobility management (EMM) software vendor MobileIron (NASDAQ:MOBL) to "help deploy applications into the enterprise."
    • Details about the tie-up are vague. MobileIron CEO Bob Tinker tells TechCrunch his company is "excited to be working with Apple," and makes note of his company's OneTouch iOS app-deployment/management software.
    • Apple, of course, announced an enterprise-focused partnership with IBM last July; since then, IBM has launched.a number of industry-specific iOS apps. MobileIron (along with BlackBerry) sold off hard when the Apple/IBM alliance was announced.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:30 PM | 8 Comments
  • FNFG

    First Niagara +1.5% after stress test results

    • First Niagara's (FNFG +1.5%) CET1 ratio reached a quarterly low of 8% over the nine projected quarters of the Fed's severely adverse scenario. That's 19 basis points lower than the bank's actual reported ratio of 8.19% in 2014 Q3, and well above the Fed-minimum allowed of 6.5%.
    • Source: SEC Form 8-K
     
     
     
     
    | 3:19 PM
  • SHOP

    Shopify makes new post-IPO highs; GoDaddy nearly does the same

    • Shopify (SHOP +6.7%) is now up 33% since news of a Facebook ad integration deal emerged on Wednesday, and 120% from May's $17 IPO price.
    • GoDaddy (GDDY +3.7%) is now up 53% from April's $20 IPO price, and within a hair's breadth of a post-IPO high of $30.86. Though the initial market reaction was negative, the SMB Web hosting/domain name service provider has gradually rallied since beating Q1 revenue estimates and providing strong guidance on May 12.
    • Shopify's quiet period for underwriter research ends on June 30. GoDaddy received bullish coverage in May following the end of its quiet period.
     
     
     
     
    | 3:13 PM
  • UAA

    Under Armour higher after creating new class of shares

    • Under Armour (UA +1.6%) is getting a free pass from investors after announcing it will issue a new series of shares which will have the effect of giving CEO Kevin Plank a disproportionate amount of power at the company in relation to his ownership stake.
    • Analysts note that the new non-compete signed by Plank takes away the Lululemon scenario where the founder of the company exits to start a competing venture.
    • UA is +1204% since going public in 2005 which gives Plank plenty of clout with investors.
    • Previously: Under Armour creates new class of common stock (June 15)
     
     
     
     
    | 2:40 PM | 10 Comments
  • RRC

    Pennsylvania regulator hits Range Resources with $8.9M fine

    • Range Resources (RRC +1.9%) is slapped with a record $8.9M fine by Pennsylvania's environmental regulator for failing to fix a well in the Marcellus Shale that the state says has been leaking methane and other pollutants into water wells and an adjacent stream since 2011.
    • The Department of Environmental Protection says it first told RRC in 2013 to fix defective cement on the well, and since then an unspecified number of water wells, a pond and streams have become murky from gas and metals; last month, it ordered RRC to submit a plan to fix the well, but rejected the company's proposal to bring the well online.
    • RRC says it does not believe its well caused methane to contaminate the area.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:30 PM
  • SXC

    SunCoke: Proposed IRS regs support coking of coal as qualifying MLP activity

    • In a statement addressing proposed new IRS regulations, SunCoke Energy (SXC +3.1%) and SunCoke Energy Partners (SXCP -2.4%) say "the proposed regulations as currently drafted support the position that the coking of coal is a qualifying activity" for forming an MLP.
    • SXC shares have bounced back from sharp early losses springing from questions arising over SunCoke's MLP status.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:14 PM | 2 Comments
  • CELG

    Receptos jumps 4% on Wedbush deal chatter

    • Receptos (RCPT) has jumped, +4.4%, to $182.35 on chatter that Wedbush has raised its price target on the stock to $348 and says a takeover is coming.
    • The company has been subject to takeover speculation, including suitors like AstraZeneca (NYSE:AZN) talking about a $200/share bid, as well as Teva (NYSE:TEVA) and Gilead (NASDAQ:GILD) discussing $280/share bids.
     
     
     
     
    | 2:12 PM | 18 Comments
  • GSAT

    Globalstar -2% as opponents confer in DC

    • Globalstar (NYSEMKT:GSAT) is off 2% as Microsoft leads a number of groups opposed to Globalstar's TLPS technology in this afternoon's "Future of Wi-Fi: Public or Private?" gathering in Washington, D.C.
    • The program also includes representatives from Google, the National Cable Television Association and the Wireless Internet Service Providers Association and the Open Technology Institute, and planned to examine the effects of Globalstar's tech on the 2.4 GHz band of wireless spectrum.
    • The company's TLPS (Terrestrial Low Power Service) technology requires an FCC rules change to permit it to operate a Wi-Fi channel at the top of that band using satellite spectrum, which it says it can do without interfering with public Wi-Fi.
    • Globalstar claimed a successful demonstration of the technology to the FCC in March, though the company's critics argued that it didn't prove Globalstar wouldn't interfere with others' Wi-Fi.
    • Kerrisdale Capital -- which put its notable Globalstar "worthless" short thesis out last fall -- argues that the coming together of once-likely TLPS bidders like Google, Microsoft and the cablecos repped by the NCTA in opposition shows that the technology is "in serious jeopardy."
    • Meanwhile, Globalstar's statement today says that Google and Microsoft are opposed because of their own private plans for Wi-Fi hotspots: "Not surprising, each has raised various issues in an attempt to unnecessarily delay or block Globalstar's ability to compete and offer consumers another choice for wireless services."
     
     
     
     
    | 1:48 PM | 5 Comments
  • NCR

    NCR +14.8%; Blackstone, Carlyle reportedly making joint bid

    • Reuters reports P-E firms Blackstone and Carlyle are making a joint bid to acquire NCR for over $10B, after factoring debt. Shares have soared.
    • dealReporter stated two weeks ago NCR has asked for first-round bids from would-be buyers, after previously reporting NCR is working with JPMorgan on a sale.
    • Following the spike, NCR's current enterprise value (market cap + net debt) is around $9.2B.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:22 PM | 4 Comments
  • HCFT

    Five Oaks -3.9% after slashing dividend

    • The monthly dividend had been $0.125 per share since Five Oaks (OAKS -3.9%) came public just over two years ago. The company last night announced a 20% cut to $0.10, a level it expects to maintain through the rest of the year.
    • The current stock price of $8.66 is about a 25% discount to March 31 book value. Shares are lower by more than 20% over the last three months.
    • Previously: Five Oaks Investment declares $0.10 dividend (June 15)
    • Previously: Five Oaks book value dips in Q1 thanks to big drop in rates (May 12)
     
     
     
     
    | 1:21 PM | 9 Comments
  • MRVL

    Cavium makes fresh highs following bullish CLSA launch

    • "While [Cavium] is seeing a slowdown in some of its markets in the near term, we expect topline momentum to be sustained for the next 2-3 years, and are forecasting earnings to yield a 28% [CAGR] over the next three years," writes CLSA's Srini Pajjuri, launching coverage with an Outperform rating and $85 target.
    • Pajjuri: "We expect Cavium (CAVM +2.6%) to benefit from product cycles in its core markets and share gains in adjacent markets such as Ethernet switching and ARM servers where the company has no presence today. At 31x [2016] PE, valuation is not inexpensive, but we believe is justified given the 20% three-year estimated topline growth and 28% EPS growth."
    • Looking at specific products, Pajjuri trumpets the ability of Cavium's mainstay Octeon network processors to both outperform standard CPUs and provide more programmability than custom ASICs, with the help of accelerator modules. "We expect Cavium to continue to gain share from general purpose processors and capture a higher portion of bill of materials (BoM) due to the growing need for intelligence."
    • He's also a fan of the company's Fusion processors for larger small cell base stations, and the potential for its Xpliant Ethernet data center switching chips (begin shipping in 2016) to gain ground against market leader Broadcom.
    • Shares are up 23% YTD. Needham upgraded 2 weeks ago, stating it was more positive on Xpliant and other newer products following Computex meetings.
     
     
     
     
    | 1:16 PM
  • WYY

    WidePoint up 9.6% on strong volume

    • WidePoint (NYSEMKT:WYY) has surged on volume of 959K shares, far above a 3-month daily average of 270K.
    • No news has arrived yet. The IT mobile/security services provider is up 25% YTD. Shares jumped last month after WidePoint posted a Q1 beat and affirmed its 50% 2015 revenue growth target.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:52 PM | 11 Comments

  • Midday Gainers / Losers

    • Gainers: CNR +27%. MBLX +17%. CHNR +13%. ADMS +12%. CDI +12%. CNTF +12%. SALM +11%. OCLS +10%. FLXS +9%. ALKS +9%.
    • Losers: ERN -19%. OGEN -16%. CNSI -12%. ISH -11%. OHGI -11%. MRNS -10%. WHLR -10%. DRRX -9%. BLCM -9%. MEIP -8%.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:51 PM
  • MCGC

    Falcone's latest MCG Capital bid gaining traction?

    • There's a bit of movement in the stock prices of MCG Capital (MCGC +1.1%) and HC2 Holdings (HCHC +4.3%) following the latest revised offer from Phil Falcone in which he promised to reimburse MCG for not just the $7M cash breakup fee with PennatPark Floating Rate (PFLT +0.2%), but also another $13.35M (in HC2 stock) if HC2 cannot close the purchase.
    • Previous bids by HC2 (now up to $5.30 per share) have done little to affect the stock price of MCG, but the shares today have moved to their highest level since the bidding war started.
    • HC2 is on the move, perhaps suggesting better odds of the company getting its hands on the roughly $175M in cash and liquid investments on the books at MCG.
    • With today's gain, MCG Capital's stock price is up to $4.72.
    • For its part, MCG Capital acknowledges receipt of the latest foray from Falcone and says its will study the bid.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:46 PM | 1 Comment
  • CNX

    Consol Energy launches IPO of CNX Coal MLP

    • CNX Coal Resources, an MLP recently formed by Consol Energy (CNX -1.7%) to operate its Pennsylvania coal mines, announced terms for its IPO yesterday, pushing ahead despite coal's decline.
    • In an SEC filing, Consol says it plans to raise $200M by offering 10M shares in CNX Coal Resources at a $19-$21 price range, and will retain an interest of 49.5%-55.8% of the partnership, depending on whether the offer's underwriters exercise an option to buy another 1.5M shares.
    • The MLP is starting out with a 20% interest and operational control in Consol's Bailey, Harvey and Enlow Fork longwall mines in Pennsylvania, and a right of first offer for an 80% interest in its Buchanan Mine in Virginia, its Baltimore export terminal and coalbed methane gathering pipelines in Kentucky, West Virginia and Virginia.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:44 PM | 7 Comments
  • BOX

    Box spikes after announcing deeper Microsoft Office integration

    • Going forward, Box (BOX +3.6%) clients will be able to "browse, open and edit Office Online files directly from Box, as well as automatically save all changes made in Office Online back to Box in real-time." By doing so, they'll be able to leverage Box's collaboration tools and security/compliance features while working on Office files.
    • Box has already worked with Microsoft (NASDAQ:MSFT) to allow files stored via Box to be opened via Microsoft's PC and mobile Office apps, and to be saved back to the cloud once a user is finished. The integration work comes in spite of the fact Box competes with Microsoft's SharePoint collaboration platform and OneDrive cloud storage platform; unlimited OneDrive storage is provided to Office 365 subs.
    • Microsoft also has an Office integration deal with Dropbox. “We are company agnostic when it comes to who we integrate with,” says Microsoft exec Jared Spataro.
    • Box has caught a bid on the news. Shares jumped last week in response to Box's FQ1 beat and FQ2/FY16 guidance, but soon gave back their gains.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:37 PM | 1 Comment
  • CASI

    CASI Pharma runs up before BIO presentation; shares climb 18% today

    • Thinly traded nano cap CASI Pharmaceuticals (CASI +18.2%) jumps on a 7x surge in volume, albeit on turnover of only 124K. Shares have increased 30% over the past five trading days.
    • No particular news accounts for the move other than a presentation by CEO Ken Ren, Ph.D., tomorrow at 11:00 am ET at the BIO International Convention in Philadelphia, PA. Traders may "sell on the news" tomorrow so retail investors should take note.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:29 PM
  • NKA

    Niska Gas Storage gains three analyst upgrades following Brookfield deal

    • Niska Gas Storage (NKA -4.8%) enjoys three analyst upgrades a day after agreeing to sell the partnership, including the managing member and incentive distribution rights, to Brookfield Infrastructure for total consideration of ~$912M.
    • Credit Suisse upgrades NKA to Neutral from Underperform while raising the price target to $4 from $3, noting that "importantly, for an undisclosed limited period, NKA can discuss and negotiate alternative acquisition proposals with third parties, subject to Brookfield having the right to match the offer or receiving a termination fee."
    • Under the deal, Brookfield agreed to lend $50M to NKA, which Credit Suisse says addresses concerns surrounding NKA's ability to support working capital requirements.
    • NKA also was upgraded to Hold from Sell at Stifel and to Market Perform from Underperform at Raymond James.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:25 PM | 5 Comments
  • CDK

    CDK up 9.4% after unveiling "transformation plan," setting targets

    • CDK Global uses its 2015 investor day to state it plans to "streamline the organization to reduce complexities," and is aiming for "free cash flow generation of approximately $1 billion over the next three fiscal years of which 70% to 80% will be returned to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases or other appropriate vehicles." (PR)
    • The company forecasts 4%-5% annual revenue growth for the next 3 fiscal years, and 5%-7% growth afterwards. The FY16 (ends June '16) consensus is currently at 7.6%. Adjusted pretax earnings are expected to grow over 25% per year on average over the next 3 fiscal years.
    • The auto dealer software/marketing services provider has surged to new 52-week highs. Yesterday, rival DealerTrak announced it's being sold to Cox Global (another rival) for $4B.
     
     
     
     
    | 12:15 PM
  • NHTC

    Russell inclusion lifts Natural Health Trends to new all-time highs

    • Natural Health Trends Corp. (NHTC +6.5%) trades higher after the company is tapped for inclusion in the Russell Global Index and Russell 3000 Index.
    • Also in the mix, the broad beauty sector is getting a lift from Coty's purchase of P&G assets.
    • Shares of NHTC reached an all-time high of $39.44 in intra-day trading.
    • Previously: Beauty shakeup has shares on the move
     
     
     
     
    | 12:09 PM | 1 Comment
  • MLNX

    EZchip +2%; ZTE using NPS-400 in next-gen line cards

    • ZTE plans to use EZchip's (EZCH) NPS-400 network processor in its next-gen carrier router line cards. The NPS-400, which succeeds the current-gen NP-5, delivers up to 480Gbps of throughput (twice the NP-5's), and is set to begin sampling in 2H15.
    • ZTE accounted for 8% of EZchip's Q1 sales, trailing only Cisco's 35%. EZchip tumbled last month after using its Q1 report to announce Cisco is expected to use an proprietary ASIC in its next-gen edge router line cards in lieu of the NPS-400. The company is still hoping to sell Cisco on the NPS-1000, a future processor expected to provide 1Tbps of throughput.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:53 AM
  • TSLA

    SolarCity +2.7%; CFO buys 6K shares

    • SolarCity (SCTY) CFO Brad Buss has disclosed he bought 6K shares yesterday at $54.87, bringing his total stake to 14K.
    • The purchase came with SolarCity continuing to trade well below an early-2014 high of $88.35. Shares are up 6% YTD, trailing the Guggenheim Solar ETF's 24% YTD gain.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:40 AM | 7 Comments
  • HIMX

    Himax up 3.1% after issuing LCoS PR

    • Himax (NASDAQ:HIMX) states its 0.22" front-lit LCoS microdisplay module won the 2015 Taiwan Outstanding Photonics Product Award from a local trade group.
    • The company uses the PR to claims the module provides a space and power edge over rival solutions by integrating an LED illumination system and a polarization beam splitter (PBS), rather than housing them in a device's broader optical engine.
    • In its Q1 report, Himax stated it "has been very busy, gearing up for early stage [LCoS] pilot production for some of its top tier customers in their new head-mounted devices." A commercial Google Glass model is expected later this year, as is Microsoft's HoloLens AR headset; HoloLens' display projection tech hasn't yet been announced.
    • Shares were up as much as 7.2% in early trading, but have since pared their gains.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:26 AM | 35 Comments
  • PFIE

    Profire Energy -11% after disappointing FQ4, below consensus guidance

    • Profire Energy (PFIE -11.3%) is sharply lower after posting a surprise FQ4 loss vs. expectations for breakeven and issuing downside guidance for FY 2016 revenues of $25M-$30M vs. $44M analyst consensus estimate.
    • Maxim Group downgrades shares to Hold from Buy and forecasts a loss for H1 2016, as PFIE expects "a difficult year" with a lack of visibility into sales in the short term due to continued capex deferrals throughout the industry.
    • Given management's weak guidance, Maxim says it struggles to find confidence in PFIE's near-term outlook and is unclear of management's underlying strategy going forward, and adds that the company still has not announced a new CFO.
     
     
     
     
    | 11:21 AM | 2 Comments
  • ADBE

    Adobe updates Creative Cloud, mobile lineup; Shutterstock -4.1%

    • Ahead of this afternoon's FQ2 report, Adobe (ADBE +0.6%) has announced its 2015 refresh for its mainstay Creative Cloud platform. The highlight is the launch of Adobe Stock, a stock photo service that's based on recently-acquired Fotolia, features 40M+ images, and is tightly integrated with various CC apps.
    • Adobe's aggressive and flexible pricing options for Stock, which targets a $3B/year stock photo market, have drawn attention: CC subs can pay $10 for 1 image, $30/month for 10 monthly images (unused images get rolled over), and $199/month for 750 images. Stock photo rival Shutterstock (NYSE:SSTK) is selling off, much as it did when the Fotolia acquisition was announced.
    • Updates for existing CC apps include: 1) The introduction of Illustrator's Artboards feature (lets users simultaneously work on multiple versions of an image) to Photoshop. 2) A fog/haze-removal tool for Photoshop and Lightroom. 3) The introduction of Adobe's Character Animator tool (animates 2D illustrations) to After Effects. 4) Major performance improvements for Illustrator.
    • Meanwhile, Adobe has brought 4 of its iOS apps - Photoshop Mix, Brush CC, Shape CC, and Color CC - to Android. Two new iOS apps are also launching: Preview CC, a mobile app/Web design preview app, and Hue CC, a lighting/color scheme capture app for video projects.
    • Two months ago: Adobe shows off new video tools, gets good Document Cloud reviews
     
     
     
     
    | 11:02 AM | 2 Comments
  • SXC

    Suncoke Energy MLP status in jeopardy, Pearson writes

    • Early losses in shares of SunCoke Energy (SXC -3.2%) are attributed to Richard Pearson's post that says the new IRS proposed ruling looks set to disqualify SXC’s income for MLP purposes.
    • According to Pearson, the IRS proposal would disqualify for MLP purposes income which is derived from activities which cause "substantial chemical change" in processing or refining; Pearson says the market has missed that the IRS Code specifically defines "chemical change" by giving the example of "the coking of coal."
    • Based on this finding, Pearson believes SXC is set to lose its MLP status; shares already have been selling off, but the author believes SXC could easily fall by an additional 30%-40% without MLP status.
     
     
     
     
    | 10:49 AM

Etsy recommends a 9-month window for product delivery, and expects most crowdfunded goods will ship within 6 months.

  • AERI

    FDA OK's favorable IOP range for Aerie Pharma's second Phase 3 Rhopressa trial; shares up 49% premarket

    • Aerie Pharmaceuticals (NASDAQ:AERI) jumps 49% premarket on robust volume in response to its announcement after the close yesterday that the FDA will allow the company to change the primary endpoint range in its second Phase 3 study, called Rocket 2, assessing Rhopressa eye drops for lowering intraocular pressure (IOP) in patients with glaucoma or ocular hypertension. Specifically, the baseline IOP range will be tightened to 20 mmHg (millimeters of mercury) to below 25 mmHg from the former range of 20 mmHg to below 27 mmHg. Rocket 2 will assess efficacy over three months and safety over 12 months.
    • This is significant because the tightened IOP range is where the first trial, called Rocket 1, demonstrated success. Shares plummeted 66% in April after the company reported that the trial failed to achieve its primary endpoint of non-inferiority (no worse than) to timolol based on an IOP range of 20 mmHg to below 27 mmHg. About 80% of glaucoma patients have IOP below 26 mmHg.
    • The FDA also agreed to allow the company to use a particular statistical approach in Rocket 2 to determine whether the trial is adequately powered based on ~240 participants. Aerie believes that it is and sees no need to recruit additional patients. Three-month efficacy results are expected by late Q3.
    • Another Phase 3 Rhopressa study, Rocket 4, should commence in Q3. Its primary endpoint will be based on the new IOP range as well. Rocket 3 is a safety-only study being conducted in Canada.
    • Rhopressa is a triple-action eye drop that targets the trabecular meshwork, the eye's primary fluid drain and the diseased tissue responsible for elevated IOP in glaucoma. It is known to inhibit both Rho Kinase and norepinephrine transporter.
    • Previously: Aerie Pharma craters 66% after hours on failed Rhopressa trial (April 23)
    • Previously: Aerie Pharma completes enrollment in Phase 3 Rhopressa study (March 24)
     
     
     
     
    | 8:34 AM
